channel.title: Gpg, share your keys here
channel.description:
lets all post our gpg public keys here.
[i]A Short Introduction[/i] gpg is software which handles public-key cryptography. This works by having keys, each person has a private key which they keep secret, and a public key which they spread around. Suppose Alice wants to send an encrypted message to Bob, she encrypts her message with Bob's public key. Only Bob can decrypt it because only Bob knows his private key.
There is also a feature called digital signatures. This is a way of mathematically proving that a message came from that sender and that it hasnt been modified in transit. Suppose Alice wants to send a message to Bob and be sure that no-one else has modified it along the way. She signs her message with her private key and Bob can verify it with her public key. Only Alice can sign because only she has her private key, but anyone can verify because anyone has her public key.
For this to work, you need to have the public key of everyone you're communicating with, hence this thread.
It asks for your real name, but I've only put yakman for the purposes of the internets.
Why am I doing this? for a bit of fun, and it might come in useful. I think its quite thrilling that you can send message that not even the NSA can read.

digitally sign file "cleartext" [code] gpg --clearsign cleartext OR gpg --clearsign < cleartext [/code]
verify digital signature file "cleartext.asc" [code] gpg --verify cleartext.asc OR gpg --verify < cleartext.asc [/code]
encrypt file "cleartext" with the public key of "yakman" [code] gpg -a -r yakman -e cleartext [/code]
decrypt file "cleartext.asc" [code] gpg -d cleartext.asc [/code]
Whenever you send an encrypted message to someone, it should be signed too. If you dont, it opens up a variaty of cryptoanalysis attacks. encrypt file "cleartext" with the public key "yakman", sign it and store in file "ciphertext" [code] gpg -a -r yakman -e < cleartext | gpg --clearsign > ciphertext [/code]
if you receive a message like this, a combined verification of the signature and decryption [code] gpg -d ciphertext | gpg [/code]

gpg --clearsign cleartext
OR
gpg --clearsign < cleartext

verify digital signature file “cleartext.asc”

gpg --verify cleartext.asc
OR
gpg --verify < cleartext.asc

encrypt file “cleartext” with the public key of “yakman”

gpg -a -r yakman -e cleartext

decrypt file “cleartext.asc”

gpg -d cleartext.asc

Whenever you send an encrypted message to someone, it should be signed too. If you dont, it opens up a variaty of cryptoanalysis attacks.
encrypt file “cleartext” with the public key “yakman”, sign it and store in file “ciphertext”

gpg -a -r yakman -e < cleartext | gpg --clearsign > ciphertext

if you receive a message like this, a combined verification of the signature and decryption

gpg -d ciphertext | gpg
